item.title: Sound of Falling, 2025 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
item.description: Second watch: that abrupt, almost dreamy movement between the stories truly feels like the right choice. The cut made that farmhouse holds as one shared accumulating identity. Incredible feat of filmmaking.
item.dc:creator: m

item.title: The Voice of Hind Rajab, 2025 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ¬Ω
item.description: A harrowing and deeply cynical exercise in Liberal Orientalism‚Äîmanifested not in the director‚Äôs intent, but in the imposition of a Western procedural structure to make a genocide digestible‚Äîit leaves a bitter aftertaste, compelling me to ask: Is the daily broadcast of war crimes insufficient on its own? Does it require the aesthetic distance of art to be truly seen?

item.title: 2024 End Year List: Documentary
item.description:
This year, I decided to separate fiction and documentary films in my end-of-year list. So much has happened in the world, and just ranking them as personal favorites felt wrong‚Äîit seemed to downplay the urgency of the issues we‚Äôre facing.

  • No Other Land

    There is no other documentary you need to watch more than this one. Against the backdrop of the ongoing Gaza genocide, No Other Land offers a searing portrayal of perpetual colonialism and the brutal realities faced by Palestinian villagers in Masafer Yatta. The film‚Äôs raw, unflinching narrative exposes the structural violence and relentless demolitions inflicted upon these communities while celebrating their unyielding spirit of resistance.

  • Soundtrack to a Coup d'Etat

    Through archival footage and an chaoting editing, Grimonprez navigates this complex episode of the start of Pax Americana order. His approach to storytelling mirrors the improvisational nature of jazz, where rhythms of tension and release echo the political upheavals of the time. Despite the intensity and fragmented nature of the visuals, Grimonprez ensures that the documentary never loses sight of its central message. The chaotic flow of images, sounds, and voices comes together in a way that distills the heart of this historical moment, making it comprehensible even to those unfamiliar with cold-war international politics.

  • Monisme

    I liked the post-colonial approach in Monisme, remind me much of Weerasethakul's Memoria (2021). What struck me most was how Rizaldi uses the figure of the mystic as a counter-narrative to the modern, scientific, rational Western worldview. Rizaldi doesn‚Äôt present this indigenous worldview in opposition to the scientist‚Äôs rationalism in a simplistic, binary way. Instead, both perspectives coexist within the film‚Äôs polyphonic structure, each presenting a legitimate form of knowledge, without privileging one over the other.

  • Dahomey

    As I wrote this excerpt, i realize the movies on my list are underlined an ongoing relevance of the post-colonial movement and its exploration of the lasting effects of colonialism. Each film, in its unique way, speaks to the complexities of power, identity, and on this, restitution,

    On Dahomey, Mati Diop brings a poetic sensibility to this weighty topic, elevating the narrative beyond legal or political debates into something far more human and profound. The objects being returned represent the stories, identities, and legacies of a people who were once colonized and stripped of their history.

  • The Gullsp√•ng Miracle

    Encapsulating the notion that life is stranger than fiction, it employs layered narratives that juggle the complexities of identity construction. Each twist and piece of information could becomes its own intriguing story. Maria Fredriksson‚Äôs direction has this uncanny ability to pull you into the mystery, and by the end, I couldn‚Äôt stop thinking about how fragile our understanding of ‚Äútruth‚Äù really is. This is the kind of documentary that lingers in my mind long after the credits roll.

    Human stories, as this illustrates, can be both fascinating and terrifying.

  • Afternoons of Solitude
  • I'm Not Everything I Want to Be
  • Ryuichi Sakamoto: Opus
  • The Night Won't End
  • Trains

...plus 1 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
